required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: TENS Trial to Prevent Neuropathic Pain in SCI
clinical_study.official_title: Randomized, Double-blinded, Controlled Trial of Early-intervention TENS for the Reduction of the Prevalence and Severity of Chronic Neuropathic Pain During the First Year After Spinal Cord Injury

collaborator.agency: National Institute on Disability, Independent Living, and Rehabilitation Research

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this research study is to: 1) test whether transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) after spinal cord injury can reduce the onset of post-injury neuropathic pain; and 2) to learn more about this kind of pain and who is at risk for suffering from this type of pain after spinal cord injury. Neuropathic pain is a type of pain that occurs in about 50% of people with spinal cord injury. This type of pain is usually described as "burning" or "tingling," and is present around the level of injury and/or in areas below the level of injury. The investigators' goal is to try a non-drug treatment (TENS) that may help prevent this pain from occurring. Pain symptoms will be compared between the study participants who receive active TENS and the study participants who receive a sham TENS treatment.

primary_outcome.measure: The percentage of subjects who develop chronic neuropathic pain.
primary_outcome.description: as defined by a score of ≥2 on the Spinal Cord Injury Pain Inventory (SCIPI), a self-report scale of symptoms

primary_outcome.measure: The severity of chronic neuropathic pain
primary_outcome.description: as measured by a self-report rating of neuropathic pain symptoms using Neuropathic Pain Symptom Inventory scores

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of participants with adverse events
secondary_outcome.description: Will collect number of adverse events

arm_group.description: Participants are given 30 minutes of TENS therapy twice a week for 8 weeks.
Electrodes are placed on participants for 30 minutes twice a week for 8 weeks without TENS stimulation.
